pros: Good Benefits, great people to work with.
cons: I am very disappointed in the way the work from home / work in office situation was handled for the finance and accounting department. I strongly believe that there should have been some sort of work from home option opposed to mandating employees come into the office 3 days a week. I believe it was a poor decision to bring back workers before the mandatory date that the second dose of the vaccine was required. Requiring masks to be worn when in the office obviously shows whoever made this decision to bring back employees doesn’t believe it is safe to be there under regular pre-covid circumstances. Times are changing and the Wexner needs to hop on the wave. Other businesses, not to mention other departments specifically at the Wexner, have given their employees the option to work from home. The hassle involved with carrying equipment back and forth to work and home adds up and causes unnecessary problems. It is also bothersome that we had to buy our own equipment using money out of our own pockets to set up an area to work from home, and now we are back in the office. After having our best year working remotely, it surprises me it was a full time change. Working remote allowed employees to have more time to work rather than sitting in traffic and having to commute to the office. Being emote allowed us to take on the influx of work that came with Covid. I know personally, I am also productive outside of the regular work hours. There are many times I will start working early morning, 6am, which would not be possible if I had to be in the office. Some days are a lot busier than others and having the option to wake up at your desk makes those particular days that much easier. I truly believe working remote will help avoid employee burnout especially for introverts. Working remote promotes a better work life balance and still allows for the same, if not better productivity. I would understand coming back into the office if there were a bunch of problems we are facing, but Microsoft teams has made it easier to be at home than even communicating face to face. Screen sharing on teams has made it even more efficient to work as a team online than in person. I really hope the decision to bring employees back will be reconsidered.

job_title: Clinical Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros:
OSUMC clinicians and researchers tend to work closely and almost all are involved in some form of sponsored or non-sponsored research. If you are interested in working within the translational medicine or clinical research sectors, this is a great place to work. Additionally, there are many opportunities to publish research and reviews, if this is a goal for you.
Co-workers tend to be friendly.
The hospital is beautiful, the french bistro in the basement is a great place to have lunch, and there is an outdoor balcony to look out over the campus while you eat.
cons:
Pay could be better. 
There can be poor communication between section directors who 'technically' head up the research and are typically PI's for the studies, and the 1-2 levels of clinical research management between the directors and the people actually doing the work. The goals of the directors sometimes do not align with directives being given to researchers/staff by lab managers/supervisors/etc. I advise attending as many meetings as possible with the senior staff and PI's so you can speak up when something isn't being accomplished in the day-to-day work, that the PI has stated to be important/a priority .. Understand the overall goals of your lab/division/dept, and you'll manage your time better/prioritize better than if you simply listen to what supervisors/managers are telling you needs to be completed. If you get the priority items finished, your supervisor looks good to the director, which means you look good.

pros: Great pay, healthcare insurance, and time off. Ratios are pretty good overall.
cons: Occasionally short-staffed, but this can happen anywhere.

job_title: Medical Claims Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: The benefits were great. You're technically working for the state so you have amazing benefits and retirement packages. Since you're also working for the University, you get the perks of free classes too. Co-workers were great and the nurses were the most amazing people I have ever worked with. It was a great entry level position while I figured out what I wanted to do with my career.
cons: There is a clear divide between Doctors and EVERYONE else. If you weren't treated like you didn't exist by the medical staff behind closed doors in the offices with them, the management sure did let you know. The only time you were really ever acknowledged by a Doctor was if you happened to wear a tie that day and they thought you were a fellow Doctor. There really wasn't room to move up the ladder unless you were clinical. You also had to make good friends with the people in HR so they would forward your resume onto the hiring managers.

pros: Great people and depth of talent
cons: Administrative burdens and shadow of athletics

pros: Good pay and benefits and reasonable work expectations
cons: Sometimes things move slowly, since it’s a large institution

pros: love working here, great atmosphere
cons: hiring takes a while so wait it out

job_title: New Grad Registered Nurse in Columbus, OH
pros: HR was great; took a couple of weeks to get back to me but just be persistent. I was with a 3/4 nurse managers and they have you rotate. The managers typically get back with you in a day or two; if they really want you that day. Then you shadow to see which floors you like best . Managers of the 6 floors that I shadowed on were FABULOUS, and I can say that EVERYONE THAT WORKS HERE ARE WONDERFUL PEOPLE. It is truly a teaching hospital. As a new grad it’s intimidating but everyone makes you feel the best and know that you can do it !
cons: Pay for parking because of the union, HR taking 3-4 weeks for getting back to know if you’re goin to be in the residency program or not. Also, there’s this constant battle between OSU West vs. OSU East. Like one is better than the other. Heck I’m just grateful to get a job at one of the best hospitals in the country and have free tuition. But it’s to each persons discretion.

pros: Education benefit is the best
cons: Parking is time consuming and expensive on main campus

pros: Good benefits, a lot of resources
cons: Poor leadership, doesn't truly value employees

pros: Great exposure to inter-disciplinary work
cons: Finding employee parking is always difficult

review_title: Ups and Downs -  similiar to many organizations
pros:
Tuition benefits for self & dependents: 100% off for self & 50% off for dependents. 
Reduced athletic tickets. 
Fabulous co-workers.
cons:
Although tuition is reduced for self & dependents there are still fees you are responsible to pay even though not used COTA, RPAC just to name a couple.  I understand that many universities & colleges tuition is free to dependents as well. 
Pay is not up to market value for clerical
Insurance is rather high 
Parking: must pay to park - almost 1K per year to park in garage.   Or can pay less and take a commuter shuttle
Respect for clerical positions can be hit or miss with leadership

job_title: Surgical Sales Representative in Columbus, OH
pros: The health benefits are great
cons: Horrible management. All about the money.

review_title: PCA - Very Good so far in my 3 years with them
pros: Excellent Benefits. Health Insurance is almost free compared to what the average American pays in their premium and deductible, which is crucial in my health needs. Tuition benefit looks pretty good too. The two units I have worked on have been good. I work at The James part of the medical center, which I know is the part that OSU is most know for and invests the most in. Supervisors have been professional and fair. In the James, I have a manageable patient load, and as a Hospital we have resources that definitely not every hospital does.
cons: Since it’s political, it can take a long time to either advance or transfer to a different unit/department. Also, as mentioned above I know OSU is known for and invests most in The James and their units. However, from what I’ve heard/seen, it isn’t quite the same in the main Hospital units. Therefore, that means higher patient ratios and therefore more stress, and not as much resources for the workers there. PCA pay could definitely be better.

pros: Used to be a great place to work, now its just another corporate job only with low pay.
cons: Expects way to much from under staffed departments and it makes it hard to have a good work life balance.  You pay to park and they then sell your parking spot for special events, too much double dipping there.  The pay is less then the cost of living, and seems to mirror the price hikes for benefits and parking, so its a net zero raise.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant/Graduate Research Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
Great benefits for all students (including graduate students).
Lots of opportunities to collaborate and lots equipment is on campus.
Compensation is good (though some departments abuse power to direct raises to a few), although it is not always performance based.
State a decided dedication to research and improving human health.
cons:
Very few people hold most of the power, and it is often abused.
College of Medicine is in a lot of debt, so good research is not being done.
Spend a lot of day dealing with an extremely inefficient and incapable administration.

review_title: poor management and workplace bullying allowed
pros: good benefits, learning opportunities, online medical library
cons: poor management, small chance for advancement, no discipline for workplace bullying, raises do not go along with rising costs of economy, have to pay to park your car in order to work and it isn't cheap.

review_title: Great starter job- don't waste your life here
job_title: Medical Records Coding Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: Amazing Health insurance. Great extra benefits and matching retirement fund. Great starter job at a Trauma 1 Hospital.
cons: Productivity is set by somebody up high who has never coded a day in their lives. A high up manager convinced CEOs to purchase a HORRIBLE product for their CAC, what a MISTAKE. Instead of listening to 100% of employees telling them this was hurting the company, they refused to listen and I watched, fearing for my own job, as other coders were being written up (on the verge of firing) for not meeting these standards. Being written up once means they get to withhold the bonus HR 'promises you' when they hire you. Mandatory overtime of 8 hours a week that went on for 3 months. You read that right

job_title: Surgical Student Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Flexibility in hours and opportunities for undergraduate research.  I could come in and leave whenever I want, as long as the work got done, and the doctors wanted me to do research for them.  I also got paid for my research because "Analyzing Data" was in my job description.
cons: Same work over and over again for very little pay.  There was also a significant lack of leadership from the division administrator to the Division Chief, people were let go or quit, and no attempt was made to hire that position.  There were also significant budget cuts to the division which led to our shredder being removed due to "budgetary constraints."

pros: Benefits are wonderful, tuition breaks for children and spouses can't be beat. Classes are available if you have time to go.
cons: Forget  any promotions, moving out of position is difficult even if you are qualified, if you bring up issues managers will not address and  then you are singled out as a complainer. Managers WILL retaliate if you say something about  problems to their supervisors. Evaluations are bias based keeping most staff from getting a decent increase in pay if any. No cost of living pay and will not increase pay if they can get by with it. HR is a joke will always defend managers not staff. Glad I have only 2 more years here.

review_title: An Institution to Start a Career
pros: A teaching hospital with horrible pay but the benefits and career jump start are good. Excellent place for people afraid to advance in their field or with only mediocre skills who show up each day
cons: Very inefficient work place, inbred as in OSU grads given supervisory and mgt positions so no influx of new ideas, no incentive for improvement

review_title: While the job on a daily basis can be demanding and difficult, the benefits of working at OSU are well worth it.
job_title: BN Case Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: There are opportunities everywhere - to progress in your career, to affect change in processes, to move throughout the hospital, to need new people, etc.  And the health insurance & retirement benefits are fantastic.
cons: There is a tendency to promote people who were good at their previous positions to the next level - which is fine if that person also has leadership skils.  However, that is not always the case and leadership is not as strong as it should be.  Some people also complain about parking, but that's never been an issue for me.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: OSU has lots of good benefits if you’re a little older and have kids. They have a lot of different jobs that you can apply to and move up the latter.
cons: Paying to park is annoying and it’s not cheap either. OSU knows that they are a big company and a lot of people want to work for them, so they pay people low. They don’t care if you have a degree and experience, they still follow their salary quote. Also in every position I’ve had at OSU, management sucked sooo bad. People were in management roles just because they’ve been there for long not because they were good mangers.

review_title: Opportunities to make a positive difference, but life-work balance difficult to achieve and sustain.
pros:
Compensation and benefits are excellent. Research resources are outstanding, especially in oncology.
Many opportunities to contribute to positive patient outcomes and to achieve measurable improvements.
cons: Such a large system that change can be cumbersome. Very  challenging to be fully accepted if not educated at OSU. New ideas not readily accepted. Defensive attitude when outcomes indicate need for improvement. Too much time spent on personal communication devices during work time at the expense of direct patient or family care. This was disappointing. Work-life balance was verbally encouraged but realistically difficult to achieve.

review_title: Too many chiefs not enough Indians...
pros: Benefits are good, most lower level staff are dedicated to a fault. Has a mandatory pension. Can cash out unused vacation time when you leave.
cons: Getting anything done with management above a Unit manager is glacially slow. Wouldn't work with school schedule, gives preferential treatment to those attending school at OSU, won't allow study materials on the unit period, half hour lunches for 12 hour shifts, little to no breaks other than lunch, short staffing results in unsafe patient loads and frustrated staff, says "free tuition" but doesn't cover lab fees/application fees/books/parking fees. Parking itself is a horrible mess especially around football game days or any events at the stadium.

review_title: Large, political, inbred, state employees with no incentive to change the process
pros:
Benefits, Great learning experience. Wonderful patients
Large variety of cases and learning to deal with new and innovative medical treatments
cons:
30 year mentality for retirement
lack of motivation by long timers, do not want to innovate or change
Departments function as silos without willingness to change.
Despite being advertised as one medical center it is actually 3-4 separate hospitals with different rules and different administrators. This contributes to the political nature of the system and inefficiency. Ultimately this affects patient care.
Despite budget concerns and no cost of living increases for employees, administrators were receiving raises and bonuses.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in New York, NY
pros: State Benefits (OPERS, cheap health care, guaranteed raise), Great networking, interpersonal relationship experience, one of the largest and most diverse medical centers in the country, Obtained experience about the different roles of each medical professional, excellent continuing educational opportunities, multiple avenues to advance career to fit ones' own personal life
cons: The pharmacy is not run efficiently, the vibe from the rest of the hospital is that the pharmacy doesn't know what they are doing. Not financially compensated well, continuous turnover due to the nature of the teaching medical campus, expensive pay to park with limited spacing, under continuous construction, under appreciated

review_title: Not bad, just remember you're a number
pros: Working in an administrative capacity, the hours are obviously not too shabby.  Everyone I've come into contact with has been helpful and polite, from maintenance to the top executives.
cons:
Remember that it is a huge establishment, and most importantly a research university.  As an employee you get the feeling that you're just a number, and you can easily be replaced.  Because of this some management doesn't take interest in your development.

Also, students get treated like garbage.

review_title: Watched my research dept change their values and culture.
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: Great atmosphere working at OSU, no matter what dept. Benefits are great.
cons: Shuttling to work from a distant parking area is mandatory for a lot of medical center staff, plus very expensive parking pass. Work atmosphere changed while I was there from a very team-oriented effort into working more and more with fewer and fewer people. Animosity from mgmt for those that couldn’t manage the additional work load. Underlying discrimination for disabled employees, not willing to work with those disabled without comparing to those not disabled, lack of empathy or understanding.

job_title: Student Nurse Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Make your own schedule, $13/hour is regular. Bonus pay is $50/4hours on top of regular pay. Many peers to work with, friendly staff. Great opportunity to get your foot in the door for nursing positions.
cons: Must schedule in 4-hour blocks. Schedules are made about 2 months in advance and are not changed. Parking is a nightmare, the Carmack lot is almost always full and the shuttle to the medical center takes 10 minutes. Because of this, plan on parking for your shift thirty minutes before you are scheduled to clock in.

pros: You will get a LOT of experience anywhere you work in this hospital. It will look great on a resume, and you'll be able to get a lot of free education. As a state job, the benefits really can't be beat.
cons: You will be worked to death. If you're lucky, your immediate manager will go to bat for you with the upper brass. But even that's a losing battle. Money mis-management is always handed down to the nurses, who frequently get denied raises to only see the hospital post record breaking profits. Can be very demoralizing if you don't have good outside outlets.

pros: Excellent health insurance benefits and great department and administrative support.  During the previous few years of economic hardship, Ohio State was one of the few universities to continue to grow.  The University has a strong commitment to its Research programs.
cons: Unfortunately, as a Postdoctoral Researcher, you are not eligible for vacation pay.  While this isn't as important during your tenure, when do we have time to take vacations anyway?, it would people helpful when leaving the University and securing your next position.

pros: Good pay for a student job, short shifts two days a week, and every other weekend. Always opportunities to switch schedule with people and to get more hours.
cons: Hospitals must serve food 365 days a year, so holidays get a little tight with people wanting to go home.  Also, fast turn over.  Almost entirely new staff from when I started to when I finished almost a year later.

review_title: Many great benefits, with only a few drawbacks.
pros: Excellelent benefits (medical, dental, vision, other discounts around Columbus), really can't beat the COESRA membership.  Job security, as long as you are actually doing your job.  Lots of chances for growth and hours that you want.  Free tuition, need I say more (if your hours allow for you to take classes)?
cons: Making employees pay for parking, and the competition for parking depending upon when you work.  Training could be better, to prepare for real world situations.  But not much can be done in the classroom.

review_title: When I was a patient there I I was treated good room was clean and the staff were very interactive with the patients
pros: Helping others working in environment that gives you the ability to interact with other people I keep a healthy and safe cleaning
cons: I have over 10 years of experience in housekeeping and cleaning I am a very good people person and it gives me time to get to know other people and put a smile on your face as well as in putting a smile on my mine

job_title: Office Administrative Associate in Columbus, OH
pros:
Good health insurance.
There is no other pros for this place but since I have to write a 20 word minimum I will just say..You are better off going to Ohio Health.
cons:
They don't pay their staff enough but yet hire people that have no experience and pay them more. 
Politics and more politics 
No communication at all within department
Management unfair and unknowledgeable, she never follows through with any requests.  
Employees should not have to pay such high parking fees or high health premiums.

review_title: Good place to start a career
job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: For those who like to continuously learn, there are the obvious benefits of working at a major research institution.  The football culture may be a boon if that's your thing, but it does add to the comradery.  Columbus is a surprisingly fun city/setting, as well.  I was fortunate to work in a smaller research focused department within the OSUMC umbrella, so ymmv.
cons: It is a very large institution, so it may be easy to get lost in all of the activity and feel like just another worker ant, depending on your role.  I do not know what the experience might be like in one of the larger areas/departments.

pros: The benefits are great, coworkers in my department are very hard working, and I enjpyed working with the patients.
cons: Wages are very low, applied to over 70 jobs to move up, the human resources department is completely ineffective, they hire people off of the street rather than promoting within, the cost of benefits has jumped by 50% in the last 9 years, and after inflation my wage is still the same as when I first started.

review_title: My life at OHIO State Hospital
pros: "You would be working for the state of Ohio, so that means you would have great benefits. There is also room for growth and development. You make good money working for the state. Going back to school is always an option with tuition assistance. And your apart of the union."
cons: " You have to pay for parking, and you still may have to walk a pretty far. There is also no set time for lunch and or 15 min breaks, so you just have to take a break whenever a patient doesn't need you."

pros: (Same review as I left for Ohio State University. The Med Center is a separate entity but the pros and cons I list are things both entities have in common.) Coworkers have been great. If you plan on staying for a long time moving up is possible.  If you go to school at OSU while employed full-time they will pay for your school. They pay half of OSU tuition for kids of employees. This benefit is good, but unfortunately it factors into your benefits package and is part of OSU's justification for paying lower salaries even though most employees never use it.
cons:
(Same review as I left for Ohio State University. The Med Center is a separate entity but the pros and cons I list are things both entities have in common.) Ohio State does anything and everything to extract money from people. As a student they charge you outrageous tuition and fees. Immediately after graduating they contact you to donate money to the school and as an alumni they never stop hounding you for donations.

As an employee, you are required to pay for parking. These are OSU lots, they are not competing with anyone else for these parking spots yet OSU puts its' cost onto the employees. OSU pays less than competitors and says it's because of the "great benefit package". The benefits are good surely, but do your homework, ask around to people you know at other big companies and you may find that OSU's benefits aren't actually that much better than other big companies. 

OSU boasts a 14% matching contribution to your retirement account. This can be a great benefit that can offset the lower salaries but be careful. You will default into one of the OPERs retirement plans and in these plans about 33% of that 14% is wiped out by mandatory fees. In the traditional pension plan you have to be at OSU for 5 years before you are 33% vested in your account and for 10 years to be 67% vested, but the remaining 33% is always wiped out for fees. The Alternate Retirement Plan is the best way to keep this great benefit they boast about. The 14% contribution becomes around 13% in this plan and you are completely vested after just 1 year. This way if you get fed up like me you can keep the money that they try very hard not to give you. 

There are two job classifications at OSU, CCS and A&P. CCS employees are essentially second class employees. They have outdated job titles straight from the 1950's. They have stricter policies that can lead to disciplinary action. They get less vacation time. They need to put in many more years of service at OSU than A&P people to get bumped up to more vacation time levels. 

Red tape abounds at OSU. Change is rare and anything that gets accomplished takes a very long time to do it. A key example of red tape is when I found myself not very busy with my job. I found a simple way I could help my team and take some of their work load. I presented it to my boss. Their response was that I couldn't because it wasn't in my job description. I had never encountered a situation where I asked a boss for more work and they said anything other than, "sure, thank you for the help."

job_title: IT Student Intern in Columbus, OH
pros: This job was nice because I was able to learn about databases and also learned decent skills about hardware. The pay is good for a campus job but nothing to brag about.  As a student intern you have plenty of extra time to work on homework and when you are working you´re walking all over Med Campus and interacting with others. Highly recommend for a busy student also in need of 10-15 hours of work a week.
cons: The job is somewhat far from the main bulk of campus. Additionally, there was alot of work to get the job like HR trails, wellness visit, online modules to complete. Pay is meh

review_title: Great place to work & go to school.
job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Columbus, OH
pros: Lots of employee benefits, activities, continuing education and personal health improvement opportunities. Lots of opportunity to advance and move up professionally. Great university and fun environment.
cons:
It's really, really big. Sometimes it's hard to feel a sense of community/involvement. 
I am a graduate research assistant so obviously the hours are long and the pay low
... but, to be fair OSU really pays us well compared to other universities.

review_title: Great health and retirement benefits, poor management structure
job_title: Data Analytics Specialist in Columbus, OH
pros: The insurance and retirement benefits provided are great compared to other firms. Medical care received on campus and associated expenses were reasonable. Managers have very reasonable implementations of work/life balance. People are friendly.
cons: Any employee appreciation attempts fall flat on their face, the exception being the Holiday Dessert celebration. For example, we were provided a miniscule ice scraper months after the last snowfall. Obtaining basic amenities like office supplies is like pulling teeth. Management has no real vision and application; task/project/employee prioritization and management is basically non-existent. Employee performance reviews (P3) have no benefit as managers will do them retrospectively for the previous fiscal year. People who work here are either lifers or using this job as a stepping stone to a better employer (turnover is very high). HR will always let you go than compete with an external offer. Yearly raises barely match inflation and your salary is extremely under market value, even at a public institution. Employees are discouraged to ask questions outside their business unit or even direct team, fostering a culture of silo'd workspaces and non-collaboration. HR management is a joke, I have seen and experienced many people's exit dates, retirement benefits, even visa applications be incorrectly submitted, causing massive operational headaches. Many employees feel suffocated and unable to 'spread their wings' to succeed. Paying for parking (CampusParc) is not ideal and employees have been hit by cars on their way to work from the parking lot due to the 10 minute walk. Career growth is slim, and salary negotiations are non-existent.

review_title: It’s not a horrible place to work.
pros:
In working the front desk...
-Once the rush of appointments and visitors calms down, you can breathe.
-The food in the cafeteria is pretty good and decently priced.
-Co-workers are, for the most part, a decent bunch. 
-It’s an easy enough job to learn.
cons:
-At busier times of the day it is hard to find a moment to breathe.
-If you’re entry level staff, you’re probably going to get talked down to by nurses and doctors. 
-Things can get stressful with handling visitors. 
-The pay is not great, to say the least.
-If you’re going part time, good luck getting hours. 
-Parking is hellish

job_title: Clinical Research Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros:
A lot of opportunity to contribute to process improvement.
Many types of jobs to move into.
The feeling that you’re contributing to  medical advancement.
cons:
Pay is below average.
Many doctors treat you like a servant instead of a teammate.
You need a thick skin as patients will yell at you for things you cannot control.
Non-research staff often treat you like you are a nuisance when you need a research procedure completed by them.  Sometimes, they even refuse which can cause big problems for you and the patients.

review_title: Find your niche, make a difference
pros: The staff and faculty are (mostly) friendly and constantly looking to advance both the medical center as a whole as well as their own careers.  Upper management has a pretty good vision for what they want the medical center to be, and actively look for ways to get there.
cons: Vision may be too broad (is that a bad thing??).  So much is going on that it's hard to know what the next "priority" will be.  Occasional PhD types would rather step on you to advance their personal agenda than support medcenter goals.

review_title: Main campus jobs are better if you want to work at OSU.
pros: OSU employment overall:  Benefits (Cadillac plan!); being a BUCKEYE!!,  free tuition for staff and discounts on dependents tuition, lots of perks
cons: Unless you are a clinical professional (nurse,  technician in a clinical specialty, behavioral health, etc) stay away from medical center jobs.  Leadership, management, and mid-management do not care about their staff, plays favorites, and are severely lacking in leadership skills.  Not a pleasant environment in which to work.

review_title: Harding administration does not seem to understand how the unit works... low pay... violent
job_title: Assistant Professeur/Chaire De Recherche in Columbus, OH
pros: flexible schedule..... could sit and do nothing all day (and some people do)..... CPI trained, CPR trained, Phlebotomy trained, ECG trained --- on the job, training is paid for...... can call off ill if needed.... could take classes for free if you are full-time
cons: must work some weekends, under paid, overworked, little respect from some nurses, violent patients

review_title: Excellent workplace and benefits... with a price
pros:
Intelligent and capable coworkers, positive atmosphere, the feeling that your work is meaningful, great medical staff, benefits. Public opinion of OSUMC is terrific and it's enjoyable to be apart of such a successful institution.

- OSUMC is massive, so my experience could easily be entirely different as other research scientists. If you are a researcher or aspire to be one then you probably already know that your experience is primarily influenced by how much you enjoy what you do and how engaged and supportive your mentor is in your growth. I have had an excellent experience. I certainly feel that my success is determined simply by how hard I work, and I'm lucky to have a mentor who shields me from the inevitable politics that float around. Overall, everyone around me is extremely capable and it feels that the means to accomplish any project are available if you have the connections to access them and the persistence to fight through the layers of bureaucracy to acquire them.
cons:
Sluggish bureaucracy, shift in research funding resources is making it more difficult to establish a research career, minor political battles, pay is less than one would receive for a comparable position elsewhere.

- As previously stated, OSUMC is huge and change occurs very slowly. I also run into too many situations when I need to complete a simple task like purchasing equipment and get five different answers on how to do so or am told "We've never done that before, you can't do that". I've typically had to push a little bit to get things done, but because the resource are seemingly endless I've never been completely stopped from doing something. Things will get done, albeit painfully slowly. At the same time, it seems like other agendas fly by at the speed of light, like constructing a new building or renaming the entire medical center.

pros: OSUMC has amazing resources for those interested in academic medicine, research, and clinical care.  In my role as a data manager, I was able to cross multiple departments in learning and collaboration. Most all I interacted with were receptive and open to sharing ideas and assistance.
cons: It can sometimes be difficult to find parking if you don't qualify for the right "pass". Physicians tend to get these passes more often than not.

review_title: Great benefits, lower pay, much depends on individual department
pros: The benefits are wonderful.  Great health insurance, flexible savings accounts for both health care and child care, and job security.  Can take classes for free-up to 10 credits a quarter.
cons: Parking can be a pain, depending on the level of your permit.  The pay is low compared to the private sector.  Politics play a BIG part in this environment...even if your job isn't academic.  Career growth can be limited, especially in the academic departments.

pros: Job security, welcoming work culture
cons:
Low pay compared to other research sites, bottle necked advancement opportunities, HR holds all the cards when it comes to pay, title, etc.
LOTS of red tape to everything... the whole institution is massive and there are a lot of checks and balances to each little process.

review_title: Stagnant environment, poor decision making and business practices at mid upper and senior leadership levels.
job_title: Facilities Services Engineering Manager in Columbus, OH
pros: Decent initial benefits package, but drastically eroding each year.
cons:
1.25-2% annual pay raises. No motivation to wish to advance or work harder.

Poor leadership structure in most areas. Despite wishing to be a workplace of choice, this organization will do very little to ensure employees and staff interests are looked after.

review_title: Get Ready for Politics in Every Move
pros:
Most of the people
Pay is good
Opportunities are present for movement/growth
cons:
Many in management do not live up to the culture that is professed
Political maneuvering
Best leader we have had was lost due to politics, while performance was top notch on all metrics.

review_title: It's okay, not great, not terrible.
job_title: Lab Service Coordinator in Columbus, OH
pros: They have a great health care program. The compensation isn't great, but I work in research and no research job really pays well unless you are the head investigator.
cons: No room for growth unless you want to get your PhD. I currently only have my B.S. and I don't want to spend the next 6 years on a degree.

review_title: There is no crying in fundraising ...
pros: Health insurance. Status. Regular paycheck. Smart and dedicated co-workers.
cons: No more secure than anything else. The need to raise more and more and more money will never ever end. But is there ever enough money?  If you're not on a team of writers, it's rough going. If you can find a TEAM, then you'll have co-workers and compatriots. Otherwise, you are at the mercy of everyone else.

job_title: RN Staff Nurse in Columbus, OH
pros: The benefits and most of the coworkers were great on the unit and definitely team players
cons: Low staff satisfaction, nrsimg staff shortage on unit resulting in frequent mandatory overtime, only being able to drop percentages twice a year and not always guaranteed, supply shortages, lack of space

job_title: Patient Care Associate in Columbus, OH
pros: I like the size of OSUMC. It provides staff with lots of resources and support through out the work day. We also have great patient to nurse ratios. Our unit is very cohesive and has great teamwork.
cons: The nurses are unionized. I do not really know much about it, but it seems to cause some delays and is time consuming. I also know some units aren't as close or the nurses are not as happy. That may be related to their nurse managers or other factors.

job_title: Senior Certified Pharmacy Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Great benefits, 10 hours of college credit per semester for free, large academic campus with lots of room for learning
cons: Difficult to move to a different position in a different department within the hospital, unorganized as a whole as an institution, invisible hierarchy that provides for stressful work conditions, very hard to get promoted with little encouragement to advance in your career

pros: The benefits. Pay could have been better.
cons: Low Pay, Dis functional team players and management. Not enough Dispatchers to do the job. Consistant work, understandable why it is to be said that it has the highest suicide levels of any job do to the continuous threats of upper management, and high stress levels of the job. I would never do it again.

job_title: Nutrition Services Aide in Columbus, OH
pros: Gain great customer service experience.  Learn how to work at a fast paced environment.  Build wonderful relationships with patients.

review_title: My over all experience has been good here, just a few small things that could be changed!
